text.p: The following are some of the leading stories in Finnish papers this morning.
- Parts of a bomb built by two 16-year old boys with instructions found on the Internet exploded in Vantaa; damage was minor but a block of flats was evacuated.
- Large crowds attended a weekend philosophers' congress in Tampere about moral issues.
- Many unversity professors will retire in the next few years, union forecast shows.

- Finnish share issues and offerings are approaching the level of the late 1980s with this year's total about to exceed four billion markka, but the level is still moderate relative to total market capitalisation.
- State asset management company Arsenal offers shares in various exotic companies such as a cable-TV station in Karkkila, an ice stadium in Vihti and a water zoo in Saarijarvi.
- City of Turku will decide today whether to sell its telephone company Turun Puhelin to a consortium of phone operators in western Finland who have bid 551 million markka. @
- Swedish Skanska and Swiss-Swedish ABB had the most profitable Finnish subsidiaries of foreign groups in 1996, measured as return on investment.
- The European Investment Bank (EIB) to finance Finnish projects with three billion markka this year; EIB official wonders why Finnish banks are not interested in cooperation.
- New daycare law has filled nurseries; many families use their right to daycare although one of the parents may be at home on maternity leave or due to joblessness, officials say. @
- Central Organisation of Finnish Trade Unions (SAK) is sson to sound out chances for a new comprehensive pay deal this autumn, SAK council decides.
